item.title: In the snow, these salamanders get supercool
item.description: Blue spotted salamanders have been seen walking across snow and new research suggests how they get by in the cold.

item.title: Scientists learn more about how human embryos implant using artificial wombs
item.description: Scientists have developed an experimental way to study how human embryos implant in a uterus, which may provide new insights into why miscarriages occur and how they can be prevented.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: What cuts to research under Trump have meant for science in 2025
item.description: Trump administration officials say changes to federal agencies engaged in science were made in the interests of better science that benefits more Americans. Many scientists we spoke with disagree.

item.title: How a power outage in Colorado caused U.S. official time to be 4.8 microseconds off
item.description: Officials said the error is likely too minute for the general public to clock it, but it could affect applications such as critical infrastructure, telecommunications and GPS signals.

item.description: Researchers retrieved reef monitoring devices that had been placed in deep coral reefs in Guam. The devices were placed up to 330 feet below the surface.

item.title: What to know about Jared Isaacman, the billionaire private astronaut leading NASA
item.description: Trump withdrew Isaacman's nomination in May, citing the billionaire's donations to Democrats and ties to Elon Musk. He was renominated last month and confirmed by a 67-30 Senate vote on Wednesday.

item.title: Italy makes a surprising discovery ahead of the Winter Olympics: dinosaur tracks
item.description: A nature photographer stumbled upon thousands of 210-million-year-old dinosaur tracks in Italy's central Alps, near where some Olympic skiing and snowboarding events will be held in February.
